H0.text: Electrochemical process is what corrosion is usually defined as: the degradation of metals due to an electrochemical process.

H1.text: Crystalline process is the cause of corrosion, which is the degradation of metals.

H2.text: Nuclear process is what corrosion is usually defined as the degradation of metals due to.

H3.text: Oscillatory process is what corrosion is usually defined as the degradation of metals due to.

A4.text: Corrosion means electrochemical oxidation of a metal reacting with an oxidant such as oxygen (O2, gaseous or dissolved), or H3O+ ions (H+, hydrated protons) present in aqueous solution.

A5.text: Corrosion can also occur in materials other than metals, such as ceramics or polymers, although, in this context, the term degradation is more common.

A6.text: Corrosion is an electrochemical process, which reveals itself as rust or tarnish on metals like iron or copper and their respective alloys, steel and brass.

A7.text: Iron corrosion takes place in an acid medium; H+ ions come from reaction between carbon dioxide in the atmosphere and water, forming carbonic acid.
